title: Nationals manager explains decision to hold back top relievers in Game 4: 'You don't chase wins'
text:
CLOSE What I’m Hearing: USA TODAY Sports' Bob Nightengale describes the mood in the Astros locker room after defeating the Nationals in Game 4, tying the series at 2-2. USA TODAY

WASHINGTON – He's pressed the right buttons all month, but Washington Nationals manager Dave Martinez finally saw his dam break in Game 4 of the World Series.

The Houston Astros scored four runs against three Washington relievers in the seventh inning, turning a manageable 4-1 game into an 8-1 runaway that evened the Fall Classic at two games apiece.

After the Nationals plated a run in the bottom of the sixth, Martinez went to Tanner Rainey, rather than either of his top two relievers – Sean Doolittle and Daniel Hudson – who hadn't pitched since Game 1 on Tuesday.

Rainey walked the first two batters he faced before getting Jose Altuve to fly out.

"Rainey has been our guy in the seventh inning," Martinez said. "It just happens he couldn't throw strikes tonight."

ALL TIED UP: Astros make World Series a best-of-three

GAME 5: Trump plans late arrival on Sunday

With two on and one out, Martinez called on 42-year-old righty Fernando Rodney to face the left-handed Michael Brantley – rather than potentially go lefty-lefty with Doolittle in the key spot.

Brantley would single to load the bases.

"He's been pitching good," Martinez said of Rodney. "He made a really good pitch to a really good hitter, hit the ball at the end of the bat, got a base hit."

Fernando Rodney looks on during the seventh inning. (Photo: Geoff Burke, USA TODAY Sports)

The next batter, Alex Bregman, drove Rodney's second pitch 392 feet inside the left-field foul pole for a grand slam.

Just like that, the game was out of reach.

Rodney remained in the game and loaded the bases with three walks, only managing to get one out. Martinez then went to Wander Suero, who struck out Kyle Tucker to prevent the contest from becoming a complete laugher.

Martinez acknowledged it would "definitely would have been different" if the Nationals had closed the gap further, rather than scoring just the one run after loading the bases with one out.

"You're down still three runs," Martinez said.

"For me, you don't chase wins."

Even though Doolittle and Hudson were fresh, Martinez wasn't going to use them in the three-run hole and was saving them for Game 5 and beyond.

"Come tomorrow we're up 2-0, and all of a sudden we're in the 7th inning – you have to use Hudson for two innings, you have to use Doolittle for two innings.

"You want those guys ready to pitch. I know we got a day off (Monday). All this was talked about before the game."
description: Washington manager Dave Martinez didn't use his top two relievers – both well-rested – in Game 4 and watched things unravel in the seventh.
